Award.AwardTitle: Experimental measurements for targeted assessments of turbulent shear flow mixing simulations

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Su
0854402

This study will apply planar laser imaging techniques to perform highly quantitative measurements of velocity and scalar fields in turbulent, axisymmetric jet and swirling jet flows. The data will support the development of subgrid-scale (SGS) modeling approaches for large-eddy simulations (LES) of turbulent mixing. Accurate representation of mixing in LES is crucial to efforts to simulate non-premixed combustion systems, where molecular mixing is a necessary precursor to chemical reaction. Very limited tests of SGS mixing models using planar scalar mixing measurements have been reported. Here, particle image velocimetry (PIV) and planar laser-induced fluorescence (PLIF) will yield simultaneous measurements of velocity and scalar fields in gas-phase turbulent jets, while simultaneous Rayleigh scattering and PLIF will measure single- and multi-species scalar mixing. Refinements to standard cross-correlation PIV algorithms improve the accuracy and resolution of the velocity and velocity gradient measurements, while strict data reduction ensures high accuracy of the PLIF and Rayleigh scattering results. Working in the gas phase allows the investigation of a range of velocity and scalar field length scales relevant to LES of combustion, from the dissipation scales well into the inertial range. The planar nature of the measurements permits spatial filtering that reflects the filtering implicit in LES. Evaluations of SGS mixing model performance will include a priori tests, as well as appropriate, grid-dependent, a posteriori assessments of LES results. These a posteriori tests will involve, besides standard comparisons of scaling properties and mean profiles, assessment of the ability of LES to capture large-scale flow organization, and true LES grid-scale fluctuations, spatial gradients, and probability distributions. The results will provide a rigorous framework for understanding the performance of SGS scalar models. This work will directly inform efforts to apply LES to realistic combustion systems, including gas turbine and internal combustion (IC) engines. Innovative IC engine technologies, such as direct injection, offer significant gains in fuel economy, and attendant reductions in carbon dioxide production. The ability to perform LES of practical engines will greatly facilitate the optimization of their efficiency and emission control. The work will also find applications in LES efforts in geophysical problems, such as those involving transport and mixing in the atmosphere and oceans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work contributes to the improvement of large-eddy simulation (LES) methods for computational representation of practical flow fields.  Among computational methods, LES offers the greatest potential for accurate simulation of turbulent, geometrically complex flows that include effects such as energy release and transport (for example, arising from combustion). However, because LES relies on modeling of the flow properties at small length scales, its accuracy is sensitive to the modeling details and to the spatial resolution that defines the small-scale cutoff.

Our work comprises both LES simulations and planar laser imaging measurements for exploring improved accuracy in LES modeling. The flow in question is a turbulent jet, which is a well-understood and defined flow system that nonetheless poses challenges to computations that are reflective of realistic engineering flows. We consider both flow dynamics and molecular mixing in our LES. The simulations employ two different modeling approaches (the common Smagorinsky model, as well as a mixed model combining nonlinear and eddy-viscosity ideas), at five levels of spatial resolution. Previously reported LES of jet flows have generally paid only limited attention to spatial resolution. The issue of resolution is particularly important where energy release is present, as local temperature differences can have large effects on the range of flow length scales that are important to the flow evolution.

The experimental component of this study involved planar laser imaging measurements, using both Rayleigh scattering imaging and laser-induced fluorescence (LIF) imaging, in the turbulent jet. Our main concern was to control the imaging parameters, and to execute the data processing, with sufficient rigor to permit quantitative accuracy in the imaging results. In particular, we accounted carefully for instantaneous variations in laser light intensity, and for instantaneous spatial variations in imaging efficiency within the field of view of the cameras. By their nature LES models cannot properly be assessed using single-point measurements; multidimensional data is necessary to mimic the spatial filtering inherent in LES. The aim of this aspect of the study was to obtain imaging data with sufficient quantitative accuracy for direct assessment of LES results.

The simulations we carried out in this study showed most notably that LES of mixing is more sensitive to the specification of the models for the flow dynamics than it is to the modeling approach used for the molecular mixing. We also observed that the results obtained using the Smagorinsky model are less sensitive to grid resolution than are those found using the nonlinear model. This latter observation suggests that the Smagorinsky results are more robust for use in simulations having an engineering design context; for design use, there would be limited a priori knowledge of expected results, so validation data would not be available for all run conditions, and it would also be difficult to identify “appropriate” resolution levels for the simulations.

Meanwhile, our experimental work has furthered the development of truly quantitative imaging methods for turbulent flows and turbulent mixing, which suggests a framework for future developments of LES methods and modeling approaches in which experimental results may play a primary role. For example, it is not clear whether our finding that LES results employing the Smagorinsky model are comparatively insensitive to spatial resolution also means that Smagorinsky models are more accurate than the nonlinear model results; this can be established using experimental data of the robustness available to our planar imaging methods.
